narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: math logic, sentential logic, first order logic, wffs, etc
Symbolic, analytical thinking.
Learned basic first order logic and really solidified proof skills.
Sentential logic, first-order logic, proof of Godel's completeness theorem.
Learnt a great deal about various logical systems and proofs in the systems.
The Soundness and Completeness Theorems of First-Order Logic, starting first with the same theorems in Sentential Logic.
I learnt about meta-logic and honed my analytical skills

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: prof shin's a good lecturer and very knowledgable. Psets can be quite difficult a times, though.

Some historical context, readings, would be nice. I left the class feeling I'd accomplished something, and intellectually stimulated, but not sure how the material fit into the broader mathematical, philosophical landscape.
Prof. Shin explains concepts very clearly, and the course is well structured. The lecture notes are also very well organized.
This course was brilliantly taught, and I dont think theres much to improve!

Professor Shin is the course's greatest asset. She is wonderful, friendly, and an excellent teacher who consistently goes the extra mile.  The class might benefit from more time for questionsprofessor Shin often asks for questions, but rarely gives students enough time to think of their questions and ask. Waiting for 5-10 seconds after asking if there are any questions (despite the awkwardness) would help here.

S- Prof. Shin is very helpful and kind -- she really tries to get you to understand the content and is very understanding. The course is a great intro to logic (albeit a bit of a harder start to logic than 115)

W - It would be a bit helpful to get a few more example problems during lecture (or after) to help students really understand what is going on.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really appreciated her extending the deadline for one of the psets. Other than that, this class ran pretty much the same as it would in a normal year.

There should have been some section / lab equivalent. The lectures, I think, should have been recorded, and available ahead of time  then, we could've spent class working proofs together, hashing out the logical subtleties, etc. Given the difficulty of virtual study groups, this would've been very helpful.
Course fully succeeded

Lecture notes are essential, and I'm very grateful professor Shin offered them. Her office hours also always proved helpful. I'm grateful she encouraged us to form a study group as wellthat wound up being supremely helpful throughout the course. If you are taking this course (Covid or non-Covid), take the initiative and form a study group!
The course went as well as possible with virtual classes

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it's a solid course and I learned alot. Btw, you do not need first order logic to do well.
Yes  but only if you have a strong background in math. It's listed in the philosophy department, but it'll be hard to survive with only a philosophical background.
I would strongly recommend this course to students who are interested in logic.
This is a math class; I'm genuinely unsure why it's listed under philosophy. If you took first-order logic and liked it, that is not a guarantee you will like this course too.
Would definitely recommend this course if you are interested in logic and logical systems.

Yes! If you are looking at this course I assume you are interested in logic, philosophy of math, foundations of math, etc. If you are and have at least one course in logic and/or proof-based math, take this! As long as you have that experience, it will not be too difficult, and you will learn about interesting results!
Yes, if you are interested in the subject material. If you're more of a humanities person, it'll be tricky, especially without having taken 115 prior
